column3:
The Stonewall Riots occur, catalyzing a larger national, if not unified, movement for lesbian and gay equality. These spontaneous, violent demonstrations, sparked off by police oppression, were credited with kicking off the Gay Rights movement in the United States.

On June 28th of the following year, 1970, the first pride parade was held in New York City to commemorate the riots.

And then everyone forgot about the role trans folk played in the riots, which is an elision from popular history that has not been forgotten by the trans community.

Source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stonewall_riots
The only Friday Night weekly event for women at HERE Lounge, cancelled on November 7, 2014.
Come get your sports on, meet new friends, and play flag football with other Queer API Women!
I had a scary experience here, and I haven't spoken with anyone about it...

I was in a faltering relationship with my ex, when I decided to get out of town and visit my friends up in San Francisco. My friend (we call her the Other Cynthia) told me that she couldn't join me for dinner, since she is going to a going-away dinner with her friend Jenny, who had just graduated from UCSF's medical school and was starting her residency in LA. She wanted to introduce us because, according to her, "Jenny has been single for two years, and I'm getting worried." Much in the style of a mother hen. We decided to meet at Dog Earred Books, here.

After dinner, we all converged at this awesome used bookstore. Then, this is how Jenny tells it. She sees me in the bookstore and thought I was cute. Plus, I was carrying a stack of books. Even better. And then, I say in a snobby-ish way, "Ugh, I want to get all these books, but I'm soooooooo busy, I don't have time to read them." Apparently that's when she fell head over heels. Or something. I proceeded to not speak to her the entire night because I was busy talking to the other.

Anyway, a few months later, after the ex and I officially broke up, and after she moved down to LA, we had a date, and the rest, well. That's the story.

column2: LA Gay and Lesbian Center: The Village at Ed Gould Plaza
column3: LA Gay and Lesbian Center. There's a gallery here, an auditorium, a courtyard, and a bunch of other resources. Events held here all the time.
Met Jenny here. I was holding 4 books and acting snobby. she liked that, for some reason.
Affiliated with USC, the ONE Archives is the largest collection of LGBT materials in the world.

Reposted from Distractify (http://distractify.com/rachel-oakley/lifshitz-vintage-lgbt-photos/):

 
Rare Photos Of Gay Couples At A Time When They Were Repressed
Rachel Oakley
 
Share this story on Facebook
71073

A rare glimpse into the life of gay couples decades ago.

 

Over the past 30 years, Parisian photographer Sebastien Lifshitz has been obsessed with vintage photographs, collecting anonymous albums from flea markets all around the world.

Share
twitter
 
 

It was during one of his searches that he happened upon a photo album belonging to a gay couple in the 1950s.

Share
twitter
 
 

 

Share
twitter
 
 

“It was quite unusual to have intimate photographs of gay people because most of the time they had to be very discreet,” he tells The Daily Beast.

Share
twitter
 
 

 

Share
twitter
 
 
 
 

Decades ago, same-sex partnerships were much more taboo, so these gay couples risked a lot by developing their film.

Share
twitter
 
 

 

Share
twitter
 
 

These photos, however, show a different story.

Share
twitter
 
 

 

Share
twitter
 
 

Each picture shows homosexuality without inhibitions…

Share
twitter
 
 
 
 

With gender norms being cut down…

Share
twitter
 
 

 

Share
twitter
 
 

And a general freedom, where love and happiness are presented without fear.

Share
twitter
 
 

 

Share
twitter
 
 

Sébastien went on to produce a dignified documentary about homosexuality in France decades ago. Here's the trailer:

Share
twitter
 
 

 

Sebastien's new book, The Invisibles: Vintage Portraits of Love and Pride, captures all these stunning images and more.

H/t: Beautiful Decay

 

 
 
Share
71073
 
twitter

Two men who are in prison here for homophobic murders married each other. See more here:

http://www.buzzfeed.com/emaoconnor/first-in-prison-same-sex-marriage?bffb&utm_term=4ldqpho#.ftPO3nyoo

column2: Gay Atheist Doctor refuses service to bigoted Christians
column3:
After Indiana Governor Mike Pence signed the Religious Freedom Law, a doctor from this small town in Indiana wrote him a letter to ask him a question. 

Story here:

http://www.politicalgarbagechute.com/gay-atheist-indiana-doctor-does-new-law-give-me-the-right-to-refuse-treatment-on-ahole-christians/
Fun place to have a meeting. Free Wifi, good food, fantastic drinks. Seems to be gay friendly, but we're not being very flamboyant.

Written by Elsa Gidlow and Roswell George Mills, this is perhaps the first LGBT periodical. Its features included poetry, one-act plays, and short stories. Along with LGBT themes, both explict and implicit, les Mouches Fantastiques was also recognized as a bohemiam critique of the Canadian middle class. 

 

Picture of Elsa Gidlow

Source

This district in Chicago was known for its vibrant gay and lesbian community in the 1920s. With its bohemian and artistic culture, gays and lesbians not only lived there, but were also widely accepted.

Source

column2: Society for Human Rights is founded.
column3:
Henry Gerber founds the first recognized gay organization in the United States. It is accompanied by the publication /Friendship and Freedom/. They only accept gay males (excluding all else), unbeknownst to them, the vice president Al Weininger is married with two children. Only a few months after its inception, the police raid Gerber's home and confiscate several items and personal documents. The organization is shut down, being labeled a "sex cult," and its members arrested for obscenity.

Source

Source (Chicago Society for Human Rights)

column2: Gay and Lesbian Coalition of Kenya is formed.
column3:
The Gay and Lesbian Coalition of Kenya (GALCK) brings together six different groups. It continues to provide medical assistance, education, and social programming.

Video:

More information: http://galck.org/

column2: “Samuel Moore and Patrick Kelly, [convicted of] Sodomy, to be executed..."
column3:
The Western Herald publishes: “Samuel Moore and Patrick Kelly, [convicted of] Sodomy, to be executed on the 15th day of July next.”

Possibly the first men to be convicted of sodomy. They were sent to Kingston Penetentiary, known for its cruel treatment of prisoners. Kelly was a probable victim to the staff, reporting a broken leg. Ultimately neither were executed, though theirs began the incarceration of gay men at the maximum security prison.

Story here: http://thedrummersrevenge.wordpress.com/2007/08/26/life-in-the-provincial-penitentiary-at-kingston-1841-1867/

column2: "Two-Spirit" as a category of gender is born.
column3:
The Third Annual Inter-tribal Native American, First Nations, Gay and Lesbian American Conference officially changes the term for "third gender" (androgynous) from the French-inspired Berdache (signifying male prostitute or catamite [receiver of anal sex]). Despite the honor that had previously been bestowed to third gender individuals, native american cultures had, at this point, been influenced by Western homophobia. To reclaim the role, they adopted the term "two-spirit."

Learn more:
http://www.pbs.org/independentlens/two-spirits/
http://www.socqrl.niu.edu/forest/SOCI454/Berdache.html

column2: Alfred Kinsey (et al) publishes /Sexual Behavior in the Human Male/
column3:
Besides it being among the first studies to explicitly consider sexuality, Kinsey's research is known for his eponymous scale, which posited fluid sexuality.

Learn more:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinsey_Reports

column2: Society of Fools (better known as the Mattachine Society) is founded
column3:
Likely the second gay (male) organization in the US, after the Society for Human Rights' short-lived span. The primary goals of the society were to  Unify homosexuals isolated from their own kind; Educate homosexuals and heterosexuals toward an ethical homosexual culture paralleling the cultures of the Negro, Mexican and Jewish peoples; Lead the more socially conscious homosexual to provide leadership to the whole mass of social variants; and Assist gays who are victimized daily as a result of oppression.

The Mattachine Society did not "die out," rather splintered into several special interest sub-groups during the 1960s and 70s.

Learn more:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mattachine_Society

MHOL (Movimiento Homosexual de Lima), the local LGBT organization, was denied permission to hold the pride parade on their requested date in June. After this denial, the organization requested to hold the parade elsewhere. The first parade was held on July 6th, with a few hundred people marching in masks, to hide their identity.


(july 2nd, 2011 parade)

Source: http://iglhrc.org/content/per%C3%BA-pride-parade-take-place-different-venue

column2: American Psychiatric Association removes homosexuality from the list...
column3:
American Psychiatric Association removes homosexuality from the list of mental disorders

Protesters successfully called for its removal from the DSM. The next year, a "sexual orientation disturbance" category arose in its place, which was then replaced by "Ego-dystonic sexual orientation" in 1980 until its removal in 1987.

Learn more:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Psychiatric_Association

column2: /Harry Benjamin Standards of Care/ first published
column3:
Published by the Harry Benjamin International Gender Dysphoria Association in its founding year, which is now known as the World Professional Association for Transgender Health. Previously known as "The Standards of Care for Gender Identity Disorders," it's 7th edition is called "The Standards of Care for the Health of Transsexual, Transgender, and Gender- Nonconforming People." Criticisms still include adoption of a pathological language.

Learn more:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standards_of_Care_for_the_Health_of_Transsexual,_Transgender,_and_Gender_Nonconforming_People

Mei Lanfang would become the most popular /dan/, female impersonator, in Beijing Opera. His performances of gender were transcontinentally renown, and continue to hold great resonances with gender, theater, and performance studies.

Learn more:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mei_Lanfang

column2: Francis Wilkinson is formally accused of buggery (sodomy)
column3:
Though later acquitted, Wilkinson was the first to be charged with sodomy in Australia.

Source: /the fatal shore/ p 265
Event for Lesbian and Queer women happening once a month

column2: Johann Valentin Müller publishes "Outline of Forensic Medicine."
column3:
Johann Valentin Müller connects sexuality with the health of the state. He critiques the idea that God punishes through disease (syphilus), stating that several innocents had contracted the disease while those known to have committed "worse" sins, excessive masturbation and sodomy, were unharmed.

Source:
http://www2.warwick.ac.uk/fac/cross_fac/iatl/reinvention/issues/volume1issue2/brooks/

Norman Haire (ed), A. Costler (ed) and A. Willy publish /Encyclopedia of Sexual Knowledge/, first illustrations of sex-change prodcedures.

The /encyclopedia/, first of a trilogy, sold approximately 80,000 copies across Europe and considered topics such as sexuality, "the technic of intercourse," as well as social and economic issues tied to sexuality, such as sex trafficking and prostitution.

Source: http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=257871

column2: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini issues fatwa allowing sex reassignment surgery
column3:
Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini issues fatwa "declaring sex reassignment surgery permissible."

Iran ranks second in the world for the number of sex reassignment surgeries performed each year. It is reported that Islamic culture in Iran is more open to sex change operations than the acceptance of gay identification. Currently, the Iranian government subsidizes up to half of each surgery, and subsequent treatment, each year (~300).

Video:
http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x85uj0_documentary-transsexuals-in-iran-pa_gaylesbian

Source:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transsexuality_in_Iran

Edith Eyde's (pen name Lisa Ben, an anagram of "lesbian") /Vice Versa/ was the first known lesbian publication in the world. She wrote that she originally began the publication to broaden her social circle. /Vice Versa/ had a total of 9 issues. In the 1950s, Ben began writing for /The Ladder,/ the first nationally-distributed lesbian magazine in the world. The complete set of Vice Versa issues is available to view at Los Angeles' ONE National Gay and Lesbian Archives.

Source:
http://blogs.presstelegram.com/outinthe562/2013/12/26/gay-history-vice-versa-nations-first-lesbian-magazine-started-in-1947-by-lisa-ben/

Occurred at Banwolseong (literally “Half Moon Fortress”)

The earliest account of homosexuality on Korea's southern peninsula was the overthrowing and murder of King Hyegong of Silla in 780. Documentation suggests his subordinates could not accept his "femininity." Historians have said that Hyegong was a man "by appearance," but a "woman by nature."

Source: http://www.utopia-asia.com/korlife2.htm

First AsiaPacific Outgames are held. Sports include tenpin bowling, dragon boat, roller derby, dancesport, and touch football. The sporting events are accompanied by a human rights conference.

Video:

Second AsiaPacific Outgames, accompanied by a human rights conference, are held.

column2: Action for Aids Singapore becomes a registered charity.
column3:
Action for Aids Singapore's objectives include to provide support and assistance to persons living with HIV and AIDS (PWAs); to increase awareness, education and understanding of AIDS and HIV infection; to combat discrimination and stigmatisation of (PWAs) and their loved ones; and to encourage AIDS-related research activities in Singapore. They were the first to operate a HIV-testing facility in the Singapore

Video:

Source: http://www.afa.org.sg/

column2: The VietROC and the 2013 Tet Parade of Little Saigon
column3:
The VietROC's request to march in the 2013 Tet Parade of Little Saigon was unfairly rejected. Being sidelined did not dampen their Vietnamese-American LGBT pride. Since then, they have been activists for Vietnamese LGBT peoples of Orange County.

Source: http://www.vietroc.org/

Barangay LA is a not-for-profit community organization serving the LGBTQ Filipino & Filipino-American community in Los Angeles. Barangay LA was founded in 1990.

Source: http://barangayla.org/

column2: The Asian and Pacific Island (API) Equality-LA was founded
column3:
Founded in 2005, API Equality-LA has been a tireless advocate in the Greater Los Angeles Asian and Pacific Islander (API) communities for fair treatment of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) people and marriage equality for same-sex couples.

Source: http://apiequalityla.org/

column2: The Coalition of African Lesbians is founded
column3:
The Coalition of African Lesbians is founded at the "Sex and Secrecy" Conference (International Association for the Study of Sexuality, Culture and Society), held at WISER.

The Coalition of African Lesbians [CAL] is a formation of more than 30 organisations in 19 countries in Africa committed to advancing justice for lesbian and bisexual women and transdiverse people.

Source: http://www.cal.org.za/new/

column2: The Gay and Lesbian Archives (GALA) is founded
column3:
In 2007 they changed their name to "Gay and Lesbian Memory in Action," but retained the previous acronym.

"GALA uses a human rights framework to work towards building a society which is democratic, just and peaceful. As such we strive to be progressive, transformative, democratic, inclusive, respectful of diversity, non-racist, non-sexist, non-xenophobic, empowering, and to provide equal opportunities. We believe in the transformation of oppressive gender relations in order to achieve true gender equality."

Source: http://www.gala.co.za/

Two drag queens known as "The Princess" and "The Duchess" held a St. Patrick's Day party at Griffith Park, a popular cruising spot and a frequent target of police activity. More than 200 gay men socialized through the day.

Originally a place to protest police entrapment, this event led to a "gay-in" which took place on May 30, 1968.

Source: Witt, Lynn, Sherry Thomas and Eric Marcus (eds.) (1995). Out in All Directions: The Almanac of Gay and Lesbian America. New York, Warner Books. ISBN 0-446-67237-8. p 210.

The Gathering of the Radical Faeries was conceptualized by Harry Hay to "connect to the ancient spirit of gay people throughout history. Seen more as a way of life than a movement, the Radical Faeries started in 1978 and had their first "spiritual conference" at this location over Labor Day weekend in 1979.

Source: http://www.radfae.org/firstgathering.htm

column2: Randy Wicker led a protest of the violation of gay men's draft records
column3:
Considered the first organized gay rights demonstration in the United States.


New York Historical Society U.S. Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street, ca. 1887.

Source: Campbell, J. Louis (2007). Jack Nichols, Gay Pioneer: "Have You Heard My Message?". Haworth Press. ISBN 1-56023-653-1.

column2: The first gay uprising in modern history
column3:
The first gay uprising in modern history occurs at Cooper's Donuts in Los Angeles.

"Two cops entered the donut shop that night, ostensibly checking ID, and arbitrarily picked up two hustlers, two queens, and a young man just cruising and led them out. As the cops packed the back of the squad car, one of the men objected, shouting that the car was illegally crowded. While the two cops switched around to force him in, the others scattered out of the car.

From the donut shop, everyone poured out. The crowd was fed up with the police harassment and on this night they fought back, hurling donuts, coffee cups and trash at the police. The police, facing this barrage of [pastries] and porcelain, fled into their car calling for backup.

Soon, the street was bustling with disobedience. People spilled out in to the streets, dancing on cars, lighting fires, and generally reeking havoc. The police return with backup and a number of rioters are beaten and arrested. They also closed the street off for a day.

Full story here: http://www.queerty.com/before-stonewall-there-was-the-coopers-donuts-and-comptons-cafeteria-riots-20111007/#ixzz2yLP6JTra


Stephen Seemayer and Pamela Wilson's film, Young Turks (1982)
Source: http://www.amoeba.com/blog/2013/06/eric-s-blog/the-cooper-do-nuts-uprising-lgbt-heritage-month.html

column2: AA group for gay alcoholics in Los Angeles met for the first time
column3:
The Alcoholics Together (AT) groups in Southern California used a unique meeting format that included what was known as the “double anonymity clause,” which protected group members from being outed as either an alcoholic or homosexual. Later, subgroups, including lesbian-centric ones, emerged. In 1982, the LA central office agreed to recognize AT groups, but only if they registered as otherwise unmarked Alocholic Anonymous (AA). Some registered, others stayed. AT still functions.

Learn more: http://atcenterla.org/history-of-gay-aa/

column2: The LAPD raided the New Year's Eve parties at two gay bars
column3:
The LAPD raided the New Year's Eve parties at two gay bars, the Black Cat Tavern and New Faces. Several patrons were injured and a bartender was hospitalized with a fractured skull. Several hundred people spontaneously demonstrated on Sunset Boulevard and picketed outside the Black Cat.

Several days later, this police action incited a civil demonstration of over 200 attendees to protest the raids. The demonstration was organized by a group called PRIDE (Personal Rights in Defense and Education). The protest was met by squadrons of armed policemen. Two of the men arrested for kissing were later convicted under state law and registered as sex offenders. The men appealed, asserting their right of equal protection under the law, but the U.S. Supreme Court did not accept their case.

It was from this event that the publication The Advocate began as a newspaper for PRIDE (Personal Rights in Defense and Education). Together the raid on the Black Cat Tavern and later the raid on The Patch in August 1968 inspired the formation of the Metropolitan Community Church (led by Pastor Troy Perry).

Source:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Cat_Tavern
http://blogs.presstelegram.com/outinthe562/2012/03/13/revisting-silver-lakes-the-black-cat-tavern/

The Palms opened in 1957 as a local hangout and changed to a lesbian bar in the 1970s. By the time it closed in 2013, it was the only lesbian bar in Los Angeles.

Read more here:

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/06/05/the-palms-closing-lesbian-bar_n_3392667.html?

http://www.latimes.com/features/food/dailydish/la-dd-historic-lesbian-bar-the-palms-set-to-close-in-west-hollywood-20130507,0,1676563.story#axzz2yLGfeu4u

column2: International Gay and Lesbian Human Rights Commission Headquarters
column3: The International Gay and Lesbian Human Rights Commission (IGLHRC), with its New York headquarters here, was launched by U.S. activist Julie Dorf in 1990 in the belief that all people, regardless of their sexual orientation, gender identity or HIV status are entitled to human rights. IGLHRC is a leading international organization dedicated to human rights advocacy on behalf of people who experience discrimination or abuse on the basis of their actual or perceived sexual orientation, gender identity or expression.

The Center on Halsted works on advancing LGBTQ community and health in the Chicago area.

Learn more:

http://www.centeronhalsted.org/

The Center Long Beach serves the LGBTQ community and interests in Long Beach, providing education, addressing physical and mental health, and organizing social and cultural activities. They also have an LGBTQ library! 

Learn more:

http://www.centerlb.org/

Started in 2011, this is first community center to serve the LGBT community in Fresno in 20 years.

Learn more:

http://www.fresnolgbtcenter.org/

Taiwan's first gay pride festival was held here on June 29th, 1997. This park is also a popular cruise spot at night.

Learn more:

http://www.utopia-asia.com/tipstaiw.htm

Two gay men get married in a small Maharashtrian wedding, then attend Mumbai's gay pride parade.

Learn more here (with pictures!):

http://www.buzzfeed.com/andreborges/mujhse-shaadi-karo-gay
There's no one here, so we're having some fun.

NYU's library of radicalism and anarchism and labor. Also has a lot of LGBTQ stuff, but the LGBTQ stuff has to be radical for it to be considered for part of the collection.

https://www.flickr.com/photos/tamiment/with/16794055068/
Andy Rutkowski working on the Damron project from here!
linzi has an awesome class who is all going to sign up for this site. :D
Great Hawaiian place here where me and a few friends got together for dinner!

In 1984, the City of West Hollywood was founded and became the first municipality with a majority openly LGBT City Council and the first with an openly lesbian mayor, Valerie Terrigno. The City continues to support LGBTQ causes and runs an LGBTQ Arts Festival called One City One Pride, was the location of hundreds of same-sex marriage ceremonies in the days after Prop 8 was overturned, has a Lesbian and Gay Advisory Board and Transgender Advisory Board, and is currently about 40% LGBTQ in population. www.weho.org/pride

Historic (analog) gay cruising territory, operating side by side the balls and bats of Dodger Stadium and the firing of pistols at the LAPD training academy.

column3:
British Museum's exhibit on LGBTQ history, Summer 2017 - October 2017

an awesome conference focusing on feminist media scholarhip.

column2: Adamant eve re-imagined, pop-up intersectional feminist cafe
column3: This is an intersectional feminist cafe which meets once every month. The organisers are two working womyn. To get to the cafe, one would need to climb two sets stair cases (we are sorry that there is no elevator), and it is in a private house in South Calcutta neighbourhood. THe organisers try to keep it small-ish (not more than 20 people), so that the discussions, performances and chit-chats are more personal. You can also find us on Facebook.

column2: Queer People of Colour meet ups
column3: This is strictly a Queer People of Colour space. We are in deep south and we often feel the need for support from people with similar lived experiences. This is an effort to create an informal group, around food, wine, chats, activism, love and lot more for queer people of colour. So far we are a very small but we are glad we exist. Looking forward to meeting new people and support each other. We do not talk about the closet, in or out as we know for some of us, the closet is the safest place and for some it is not. Look forward to meeting new folks who are queer people of colour.

Between 2014 and 2016, we had a pretty active group of QTPOC folks here in Calgary, making art, performing, making movies, having potlucks etc. We also used to host potlucks when QTPOC individuals travelling from different parts of Canada were passing through Calgary. As we were also members/organisers for Beyond Borders(2014-2015), a program dedicated to immigrants/ non-immigrant workers or refugee claimants, queer folks of colour, we could also write letter of references for immigration court appearances. The group also taught several workshops for Calgary OutLink, and Mount Royal University.This group made a movie for Calgary Gay Film Festival in 2015, which was screened at the festival. It was an amazing experience meeting so many awesome QTPOC artists, performers and friends. Beyond Border was shut down when the facilitators of the group called LGBTQ organization, which was the host of this program, for institutionalized racism. The last public appearance for Beyond Borders (2014-2015) was a community meeting held by Beyond Borders group and their supporters at Community Wise Resource Center in August 2015. Though Beyond Borders was forced to shut down, the QTPOC group continued, several of the group members still live in Calgary, and some are scattered around Canada/USA.Between 2013 and 2016, we had a pretty active group of QTPOC folks here in Calgary, making art, performing, making movies, having potlucks etc. We also used to host potlucks when QTPOC individuals travelling from different parts of Canada were passing through Calgary. As we were also members/organisers for Beyond Borders(2014-2015), a program dedicated to immigrants/ non-immigrant workers or refugee claimants, queer folks of colour, we could also write letter of references for immigration court appearances. The group also taught several workshops for Calgary OutLink, and Mount Royal University.This group made a movie for Calgary Gay Film Festival in 2015, which was screened at the festival. It was an amazing experience meeting so many awesome QTPOC artists, performers and friends. Beyond Border was shut down when the facilitators of the group called LGBTQ organization, which was the host of this program, for institutionalized racism. The last public appearance for Beyond Borders (2014-2015) was a community meeting held by Beyond Borders group and their supporters at Community Wise Resource Center in August 2015. Though Beyond Borders was forced to shut down, the QTPOC group continued, several of the group members still live in Calgary, and some are scattered around Canada/USA.

After months of swimming in denial, shying away from each other, and employing all sorts of silly evasive manuevers, I kissed my future-wife here for the first time. Took us a while, but we were ready.

Our mission statement:The Lesbian, Gay, Bi & Transgender Community Organization's mission is to provide a focal point for the members of our community in the South Bay for education, social interaction, personal growth, and political power, and to foster public understanding of our community.

 

For more information, please visit the South Bay LGBT Center's official site.

On our trip to Vienna in June 2018, we wanted to see what gay life was like, so thanks to Google, we found this little cafe that serves beer and wine. Very gay, lots of older gay men were sitting along the patio outside. We joined them and spent the rest of the evening watching cars and the bustle across the street at the Night Market.

When this collection moved to its new location on Hudson Ave in 1979, it is renamed the National Gay Archives: Natalie Barney/Edward Carpenter Library.
